transcript.text: In this video, I'm going to fully
explain one of the most important
aspects of freestyle snowboarding, the
landings, and the techniques that pro
snowers use in order to ensure that
their landings are consistent, safe, and
ridiculously effective. And the
different tweaks you need to make for
different features and different tricks.
And by the end of this video, you won't
only understand why these body mechanics
are so useful, but also how to implement
them into your own riding. Every landing
is based around the same stacked
position and we want to be shifting it
and adjusting it depending on what the
feature wants. So here I'm doing a
pretty perfect jump so both feet are
landing at the same time. But what's
important isn't the fact that my board's
hitting at the same time. It's my upper
and lower body angle. Notice how in this
jump my upper body is pulled forward and
my hips are pulled back. This is making
it so my weight is completely centered.
But because of the staggering in the
upper and lower body, I have the ability
to move my legs independently to my
upper body. I don't need to in this
instance because I got a good enough pop
that I can land with both feet at the
same time. So alls I need to do is
extend my legs, catch the landing. And
this is a really important part whenever
landing on your snowboard. You always
want to be meeting the landing. You
don't want to be falling into the snow.
Instead, you want to be extending into
it because not only does this increase
the range of motion you'll have in your
legs to absorb the impact, but also it
eats up a little bit of that impact as
you go and put your legs into it. A rule
for this is we never want to be fully
extending your legs. Notice how there's
a little bit of bend in both of my
knees. If you fully extend your legs,
you're going to be locked out and it's
going to put a lot of impact into your
joints. So, we want a little bit of bend
that we can comfortably go and squat
down into. When we're landing, we want
to land with a little bit of weight set
over the balls of our feet. We do this
by having our hips kicked out and our

when we squat down, our weight stays set
over the same point. You can see that
it's almost completely flatbased, but
it's enough edge pressure that I don't

weird snow. And edge pressure is going
to be extremely important for some other
landings, especially once we start

drastically overshoot the jump. This

coming into the landing. So now, as I'm
adjusting, trying to rebalance, I'm
heading to the flat part of the landing.
So I can't land with my board on that
nice consistent angle. Instead, I'm
going to need to tilt my hips in order
to change the angle of my snowboard. And
that's the power of this position.
Because I have this stagger in my upper

independently. So here, I'm pushing my

coming up, and you're going to see that

extended but not fully. This position is

upper body forward. Weight still set

the reason why we can get away with

pulled forward, when we combine that

the slope. This is the technique used by
every pro snowboarder, including someone

keeps that angle, lands tail heavy,
pushes through. So, as he leaves the

He's coming in and landing with that

the whole angle in the tail of your

On any blind landing tricks like this

And we can see with the nose down,

Make sure my weight set over the balls

Because if you land toeheavy in this
